text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. This is a short but fun video about

laughter. How often do you laugh? They say 
that people who laugh a lot from the heart

live happier lives. Laughter 
is a form of stress relief.

Of course, cruel laughter isn't good for anyone, 
so surround yourself with healthy forms of humor.

"Laugh" is both a noun and a verb. You can have 
a loud laugh or a soft laugh. You can laugh.

You can laugh at something, like you can laugh 
at a silly joke. You can laugh at yourself.
You can laugh about something silly you did.

Sometimes we have to explain that we're 
laughing with someone and not at someone.

If you want to talk about being brave, you 
can say, "I laugh in the face of danger.

Ha! I'm not afraid." But how do we laugh? 
Do you always laugh the same way? I don't.

A joke that's a little funny, but not 
terribly funny, might make me chuckle.

That's a low quiet laugh 
often with our mouth closed.
If I'm feeling silly, I might giggle.

Giggling is quick and high-pitched. It's a 
series of laughs. People of all ages might

giggle when they feel nervous, so it's 
not always a positive form of laughter.

An unexpected source of humor might make 
me burst out laughing. That's what it means

to guffaw. Guffawing is loud laughter. It's a 
big ha or hahaha. It doesn't sound very nice.

What's even worse is snorting. Some people 
snort when they laugh. That's making a loud

noise through your nose. Thankfully, I don't do 
this too often. Let me see if I can snort for you.

And one final way of 
laughing? Well, here's a hint.

Witches cackle. In movies and storybooks, witches 
always cackle. They laugh in a loud, mean way.

Cackling is a loud, mean version of 
giggling. Let's see if she'll cackle for you.

So how do you laugh? I bet if you record 
yourself laughing and then listen to it,
you'll laugh in a different way. Try it.
Remember these words and phrases:
chuckle, giggle,
burst out laughing,
guffaw, snort, snort with laughter, cackle.

That's all for now. Please like the video 
if you found it useful and interesting.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and 
Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon?
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
